content.content: Summary RWA exposure is increasing sharply to 537M DAI at the end of November.  image795×349 11.4 KB  RWA represents now more than 50% of MakerDAO expected revenues (adding 18% if you count GUSD).  image795×336 16.7 KB  On the liquidity front, 75% of the assets (400M) are deployed in cash-like investments and could be recovered in a few weeks with a friction expected cost of 0.3%.  Monitoring notes Strategic Finance has started to take over RWA monitoring. No evidence of any monitoring by the RWF facilitator have been found. @roo , credit analyst, will take the lead n the next few months. Community should expect it will take a few months and be an iterative process without all collateral under consideration initially.  Collaterals  MIP65 - Monetalis Clydesdale Exposure to MIP65 was $401M at the end of November. The value of the underlying portfolio was $400M, the difference being some setup and transaction cost. For instance, we paid 15bps (600k at end of the period) for the Swiss stamp duty. Community should consider a 30bps friction when we buy or sell. Reducing this friction is obviously important. We are currently earning a bit north of 4% on those asset after arranger and custodian costs which represents 1.6M DAI per month (at 500M exposure). Exposure is 2/3 0-1yr maturity and 1/3 1-3yr maturity.  image798×354 18.5 KB  The Dune dashboard provide more informations and we are working on a more detailed and accurate V2.  HVB HVB is now in green territory thanks to interest earned on idle cash. Loan outstanding are 17M out of a 100M facility.  image1089×533 31.2 KB  After we finish to stabilize New Silver monitoring, we will move to HVB. For instance, some label are still a bit unclear and we don’t have loan characteristics. No monthly audit call was performed. Dashboard (still under construction)  New Silver New Silver is close to 13M exposure. We performed a monthly audit call and found nothing to report. We still have due diligence on the manager to perform. @roo will perform a credit assessment regarding the debt ceiling increase.  image840×846 60.5 KB

SebVentures:  We still have due diligence on the manager to perform.   What type of DD is typically performed here? Are you underwriting to a manager’s track record, asset class, cost of capital, cap rates, etc? Does duration/liquidity factor in? Also, is there a preferred organizational structure and legal framework for these managers to follow? Playing a bit of catch-up reading through the forums so if this has been answered already just let me know.

SebVentures:  We are currently earning a bit north of 4% on those asset after arranger and custodian costs which represents 1.6M DAI per month (at 500M exposure). Exposure is 2/3 0-1yr maturity and 1/3 1-3yr maturity.   Your calculation seems high when looking at the performance of these individual funds - iShares $ Treasury Bond 0-1yr UCITS ETF | IB01, Exchange-Traded Funds (ETFs) | iShares UK – BlackRock  - some clarity as to how you reached this 4% earnings estimate. Also what do you mean by “earning” - in finance you only earn when you sell the investment. As it is intended that MIP65 will liquidate accumulated NAV added during the month as Maker’s return to the SB - what is Maker’s projected cash return net of all commissions - given the performance to date.

Thank you for providing an update on HVB. Hopefully the DAO will get more clarity on the loan characteristics, soon™.  More than likely both HVB and New Silver will see a slowdown in mortgage activity, as mortgage applications have fallen by more than 40%++ as the FED continues to tightened and home prices have already peaked.

SebVentures:  HVB is now in green territory thanks to interest earned on idle cash   Are we getting interest on idle cash? I had a vague recollection that idle cash might be invested in treasuries, but when I voiced this some weeks ago, you said that idle cash was strictly idle. Can you clarify? If we’re getting interest (great!), what is the interest rate?

SebVentures:  We are currently earning a bit north of 4% on those asset after arranger and custodian costs which represents 1.6M DAI per month (at 500M exposure). Exposure is 2/3 0-1yr maturity and 1/3 1-3yr maturity.   What is the net exposure per maturity date after taking into account the cash allocation of individual funds?

Also what do you mean by “earning” - in finance you only earn when you sell the investment. As it is intended that MIP65 will liquidate accumulated NAV added during the month as Maker’s return to the SB - what is Maker’s projected cash return net of all commissions - given the performance to date.  Totally agree with this. I have not been paying close attention to our RWA methodologies, but am curious as to how often do we take profits from all these RWA efforts. It definitely is desireable to take profit as often as possible to realize our profits and get an ROI for our investment.

freehold:  What type of DD is typically performed here?   On the monthly one we inspect documents, check that all is in order, so that the data reflect reality. The annual one is to check the financial health of the counterparties. I will leave it to who’s in charge to define what is best.     dbkcan:  Your calculation seems high   You can check Yield to maturity which is provided in the link. I deduct 15bps for Monetalis and 5-10bps for custody. This is what I look at instantaneous looking forward earnings which is what make sense business-wise. I leave you to define whatever earning you want. Finance has move towards fair value through profit or loss, for instance in IFRS 9. For historical PnL, we plan to recognize earning when they hit the Surplus Buffer. Not because it is accurate (which it is not), but because it is more convenient and simpler to understand. Off-chain accounting should be a temporary thing before everything moves on-chain. Community can follow the discrepancy between what is recognized in the Surplus Buffer and the actuals with the report, ideas is that with one payment per month it remains very small.     psychonaut:  Are we getting interest on idle cash?   This is my current understanding (HVB related).     0x336c6:  What is the net exposure per maturity date after taking into account the cash allocation of individual funds?   On average it is 1 year with an overweight in the less than 1 year part (and up to 3 years). You can dig in the exact composition of each ETF. They don’t hold meaningful position of cash (and any cash at the legal structure, the BVI Trust, is disregarded for now).

SebVentures:  On the monthly one we inspect documents, check that all is in order, so that the data reflect reality. The annual one is to check the financial health of the counterparties. I will leave it to who’s in charge to define what is best.   Appreciate the response @SebVentures – I believe one of the biggest challenges / opportunities on our doorstep is to translate the same rigor with which the industry is focused on proof of reserves and proof of solvency to due diligence and valuation of RWAs. This is a step-function improvement and an entirely new model that has not existed in traditional finance, and which a blockchain-based Oracle has a unique ability to create in a trustless way. Is anyone working on this right now? Without the ability to understand underlying collateral in real-time, we’re leaving ourselves at a massive disadvantage in evaluating risk. This is particularly troublesome when we consider the regulatory uncertainty around a DAO (or associated legal wrapper) being recognized in a court of law and having the ability to enter into any sort of adjudication process in the result of a margin call. If there isn’t anyone working on this, I’d love to help solve this challenge.

@SebVentures  Congratulations on launching RWAs at an impressive pace.  After we finish to stabilize New Silver monitoring, we will move to HVB. For instance, some label are still a bit unclear and we don’t have loan characteristics. No monthly audit call was performed.  On HVB, do we have any idea what loan types were purchased? I think scaling with banks is a no-brainer, but it seems problematic that all of the exposure is concentrated with one (especially one as small as HVB) and the visibility is limited. It would be interesting to compose a bank portfolio that is more diversified across loan types, originators, and geographies. Given most banks have much more sophisticated reporting systems than HVB, think there is a real opportunity to parse loan-level data and report that to the community. These off-chain deals are essential but no reason we can’t improve substantially on how we execute. - especially if we want to scale this responsibly! Would love to connect with you and/or @roo on this.
This topic was automatically closed 90 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
